div1.p: Consulat Général De L'État Indépendant Du Congo. Baltimore.
le 23 janvier 1908.
Monsieur le Chevalier,

Comme vous savez, Monsieur Smith, un agent de la Société Internationale Forestière et Minière du Congo, a ecrit une lettre assez sensationelle et inexacte à ses amis en Amerique qui ont en l'indiscretion de livrer sa correspondance à la presse.
A facon d'empecher une repetition de cette erreur j'ai cru utile d'ecrire un mot à Monsieur Beatty, un des Administrateurs de notre société, qui a choisi Monsieur Smith et qui la proposé comme agent.
Monsieur Beatty vient de m'ecrire qu'il a pris des precautions necessaires pour en eviter une repetition.
J'ai l'honneur de vous transmettre copie de la correspondance que j'ai eu avec Monsieur Beatty à ce sujet.
Veuillez agréer, Monsieur le Chevalier, l'assurance de ma consideration la plus distinguée.
James Gustavus Whiteley

div1.p: Copie.
Personal & unofficial.
January 17th 1908.
My dear Mr. Beatty:-

You will observe that Mr Arthur F. Smith's sensational account of the adventures of our expedition in Africa is being used to create a false impression of the spirit which animates our company and the Government of the State.

I know nothing of the accuracy of his description but the fact that he has treated a regrettable incident in a sensational and flippant way has encouraged certain papers to impute a spirit of callousness to the company and to the Government from which the concession was received.

What I wish to call your attention to in Mr Smith's letter, as published, is that he states: "Everything in the Congo is in the hands of a few big corporations in which the State, or rather the King, owns one half".
As you are aware it is the State and not the King personally that owns a half interest in these concessions.

It is unfortunate that an employe of our company (who ought to be better informed and who is supposed by the Public to be well informed) should contribute to spreading the false impression that the King has a personal interest in the matter.
It is a point which I have spent a great deal of time endeavoring to make clear to the public, and I thought you might wish (in an informal way) to call Mr Smith's attention to the fact.

very sincerely yours
(signed) James Gustavus Whiteley.
Consulate General of the Independent State of the Congo. Baltimore.
January 23, 1908.
Sir Knight,

As you know, Mr. Smith, an agent of the International Forest Society and Minister of the Congo, wrote a letter quite sensational and false to his friends in America who have the indiscretion to deliver their correspondence to the press.
A way to prevent a repetition of this error I believed useful to write a word to Mr. Beatty, one of the civil servants of our society, who chose Mr. Smith and who proposed him as an agent.
Mr. Beatty has just written me that he took the necessary precautions to avoid a repetition.
I have the honor transmit a copy of the letter that I had had with Mr. Beatty about this subject.
Please accept, Sir Knight, the assurance of my most distinguished consideration.
James Gustavus Whiteley
